importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The research voyage to the Gascoyne Marine Park took place in late 2022, marking a key moment in the discovery of new deep-sea species.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The discoveries made during the 2022 expedition have had ongoing scientific significance, with estimates suggesting around 600 more species remain to be described and named by 2025.

keyTakeAways: A semi-transparent porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in size, was discovered at a depth of 122 meters, using hairs to catch food instead of claws.
A new species of lantern shark, the West Australian Lantern Shark, was found at over 600 meters below sea level, growing up to 40cm with glowing photophores on its belly.
The discoveries were made during a research voyage led by CSIRO in the Gascoyne Marine Park, 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
The findings highlight the vast biodiversity in Australia's unexplored deep-sea regions, which are home to species not found elsewhere on Earth.
About 20 new species have been described so far, including the Carnavon Flapjack Octopus, and scientists estimate around 600 more remain to be formally identified.

namedEntities.name: West Australian Lantern Shark
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A newly discovered species of lantern shark found in the deep sea, growing up to 40cm with glowing photophores on its belly.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species was directly discovered during the deep-sea expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park and is a key example of new deep-sea biodiversity.

namedEntities.name: Porcelain crab
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new type of porcelain crab, about 1.5cm in size, found at 122m depth, feeding via modified mouthparts with hairs rather than claws.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: This species exemplifies unique feeding adaptations and contributes to the broader understanding of deep-sea crustacean evolution.

namedEntities.name: Carnavon Flapjack Octopus
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A new species of octopus, approximately 4cm in size, with a rusty red coloration.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: One of the 20 newly described species, it underscores the diversity of marine life in the deep sea and adds to the catalog of Australian biodiversity.

namedEntities.name: CSIRO
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Australia's national science agency that led the deep-sea research expedition.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: CSIRO conducted the 2022 research voyage into the Gascoyne Marine Park, playing a central role in the discovery and documentation of new species.

namedEntities.name: Gascoyne Marine Park
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A marine protected area located about 20km off the coast of Western Australia.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The expedition took place in this area, which is one of the least explored regions of Australia's ocean, making it a key site for biodiversity discovery.

namedEntities.name: Western Australia
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A state in Australia, where the research was conducted and where the newly discovered species are found.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Western Australia is a major hub for deep-sea exploration and is recognized as a global biodiversity hotspot.

namedEntities.name: Dr Will White
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A fish scientist involved in the research, providing expert insight on lantern shark bioluminescence.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr White's scientific explanation of lantern shark bioluminescence adds credibility and educational value to the discovery.

namedEntities.name: Dr Andrew Hosie
namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: Curator of aquatic zoology at the Western Australian Museum, involved in the porcelain crab study.
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Dr Hosie provided key insight into the feeding behavior of porcelain crabs, contributing to the scientific understanding of the species.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Australian scientists from CSIRO discovered two new deep-sea species during a 2022 expedition in the Gascoyne Marine Park, 20km off Western Australia's coast. These include the West Australian Lantern Shark, a bioluminescent shark found over 600 meters deep, and a tiny porcelain crab, 1.5cm in size, feeding on plankton using specialized hairs. The findings highlight Australia's rich but underexplored marine biodiversity, with around 20 species now described and an estimated 600 more awaiting formal classification. The discoveries underscore the importance of deep-sea exploration in advancing global scientific knowledge.
title: Australia: Almond-sized crab and tiny lantern shark discovered in deep seas
